transcript.content: Elliott Guilbeau REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My name is Elliott Guilbeau I been locked up for 30 years I was 20 years old when I got arrested and I'm down for murder 2nd degree murder.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok thank you so the point of this interview is for me to try to learn about you and your life history your childhood and adolescence before this and of course the majority of your life which has now been here at Angola.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So let me start by asking you about your family. Tell me about the folks who raised you.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My mom and my dad and I'm the second child third child of five child I got a brother and sister older and brother sister younger than me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and where did you grow up?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Grand Choteau Louisiana.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright so was that in kind of a rural area as opposed to you weren't in a densely populated houses all close together was it more like the country.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It's a little country town.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Between Opelousas and Lafayette.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah ok. Religious family were you going to church.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: We go to church every Sunday.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Every Sunday okay.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My dad he worked he was the mostly gone most of the time but mom she took us to church every Sunday.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, did your parents get along have a good relationship?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yep.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, did they stay together throughout your childhood?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right they're still together today.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow tell me a little bit about your siblings what are their names.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I got an older brother named David Guilbeau a sister Marie my little sister charlotte man she's married now she stay in Denver and I got a little brother Catalan Guilbeau he's in Arizona.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright so two of the other siblings stayed in Louisiana the two older ones.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok and are you still in touch with them all now.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah do they come and visit you up here.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Regular.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Regularly who comes who comes here?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My older sister my little sister and my little brother and my mom and my dad my older brother he don't like coming up here but I talk to him all the time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok so I think I'm getting from what you're saying I'm gathering that you grew up in a fairly secure family where you knew you were cared for or did you feel like you kind of had to make it on your own which one.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: They cared for me but I was the type that I always thought that I was outcast because I felt that they always looked up to them more than me cause everything I got I got on my own like from growing up I everything my money I cut grass. So I really never asked them for nothing and when I did ask for something they wouldn't give it to me because they knew I had that so I felt that I was outcast on that

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok so yeah how else you are the middle child right bang smack in the middle and so in what other ways did you feel like an outcast child.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well a lot of times I would ask for stuff they wouldn't give it to me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok but they would give it to the others.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: But they would give it to my little brother and my little sister.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My older brother and sister they was gone most of the time so to their friends so they didn't ever ask for nothing.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright did any of your siblings get in any kind of trouble with the law?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: No none of them

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, and were you were you in trouble with the law prior to this particular charge?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I stayed in trouble with the law.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You stayed okay, and we'll get to that in a minute what about grandparents any close relationships with grandparents.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My mom's mother she used to watch us all the time when mom would go to work and I remember I was about 5 years old me and my older sister we almost died because we went on top of her little watch house with my older brother and our cousin and we thought it was some salt and we ate some lye and me and my older sister almost died had to stay in the hospital a few months.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow gosh and that was when you were in the care of your grandparents?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right and my me and my grandmother on my dad's side we never did get along me and her stayed till wanted to shoot each other and pulled guns on each other.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow okay, who do you think would be the person you could say you got along best with coming up whether it's friend family who would that be.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My little sister and little brother I always felt that I had to look over them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, and you felt that was there somebody you thought that you could go to if you had a problem that you could talk to and really could try to understand you coming up or did you feel like I kind of have to figure it out.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Nobody till I was about 12 years old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Then I got this job at a little store called pop and pack by my house I was 11 when I got that job and they kind of took me as they child and want me to start staying with them because me and my dad we stayed fighting all the time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: And I refused to go stay with them because I told them I wouldn't have no more friend s which I should have because I wouldn't be here today.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So those tell me more about that fighting with your dad.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I always wanted things my way like I come in at night 2 3 o'clock in the morning I wasn't more than 12 years old and I felt I was a man so he'd try and keep me from going out staying out all night.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, things get physical with you?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right well I would get physical with him he wouldn't really hit me back and try to stop me holding me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right ok. So what do you thinks causing all that anger in that little boy.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I never felt I was for them I always felt that I told my mom I said I'm not your child won't y'all tell me who my real parent is and I'll go back I always told them I was an alien because I had this little thing I made my ears move I made my nose move and I told myself a real child don't do that so she'd back but who you think carried you boy I'm your mama.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah but mama I just kept that thought and then after the years being incarcerated that's when I really started getting close to my family but until then I never cared for them I cared for nobody not even me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure sometimes it takes that time to create the perspective back on what you had sure what about school I'm going to assume that school was not that interesting to you from what you're saying.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: No I hated school I got kicked out of school.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok behind what.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I skipped school for homecoming went drinking and come back to school at 12 o'clock for last periods and asked the teacher if I could go use the bathroom she said no. So I said ok I told my guy on the side I said look I'm do I'm going to use the bathroom in the desk so I kneeled down to the desk and used the bathroom in the desk and he told the teacher on me so they expelled me the rest of the year.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sure so what was the highest year of school that you completed.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: 8 but they would pass me just to get me out they classes I was not ever do nothing but they just didn't want to trouble of me anymore.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right no not that too so I'm trying to get a better picture of your neighborhood if you told me I'm familiar with New Orleans but I'm not familiar with Grand Choteau so if I'm sitting if the two of us how old are you now?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah 51 I'm a couple years behind you so if we if the two of us as teenagers are sitting on your front porch can you describe what would I be seeing what would I what other paint a picture for me a little.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: You looking at my aunts trailer and my grandmother's house and then you be looking at the park cross the street from the house and the city hall. And then in the back of the house then you be looking at the highway.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright so it's sort of like a small town feel.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It's a real small town it's like only have 1100 people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so there's not a whole bunch of people in the street.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: No okay, alright. Well tell me about the first time you got arrested.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It was 85 December 85 me and my brother got into it. I was drinking and he seen me down this road and told me said man what you gone be drinking you drunk and I hit him we start fighting because he try to make me go home. So my mom told me the next morning she come see me Sunday morning, she said David said he gone get you out of jail, but he scared because you told him you gone kill him. I said yeah tell him, I'm going to kill him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you got arrested that night and went to jail.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right that was by an adult but the first time I got arrested or a juvenile I went to the boy's home.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and what was that behind.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Me and my dad got into it and I pulled a knife out on him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay alright. So it's all fighting it sounds like.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Mostly.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you have any arrests that had to do with anything other than fighting?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I had marijuana arrests.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, we don't actually have to get that much further into that what about any kind of relationships you might have had with girlfriends that stand out in your mind now.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah I had one girl Patricia she used to beg me to quit drinking and sometime I would quit for about a week and then like I just can't do it no more so she wound up leaving me because I had a real drinking problem and a drug problem.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Any children?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: None.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright did you yourself have access to a firearm?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I had a pistol one time and that got took from me at the racetrack event that I was doing. I pull out on a couple of guys.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok I'm trying to figure out if you now that you've had 30 years away from that all when you look back do you is it easy for you to identify the why question like why what caused all that is there something specific or do you have a sense of it now.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I started drinking at an early age I started drinking when I was 7. And I think that's what brought it on cause long as I wasn't drinking or on drugs I was the best person you can be around.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright, so it was substance abuse it was drug addiction and alcoholism ok that makes sense so what do you think would have happened if this didn't happen this particular charge would it have been something else how do you see the rest of your life going at that point in your life.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I'd probably be dead I think somebody would have killed me or I probably would have OD'd.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So is it then accurate to say that being arrested for this may have saved your life.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: In a way yeah because I can think see where I went wrong in life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah did you were you able to continue using drugs and alcohol once you were arrested in the parish.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I could have but I chose not.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right sure how long did you spend in the parish while you're going through the trial.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: 4 years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's a long time.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well after I got I got convicted in 90 and they just kept me in the parish because of one my friends I went to school with was dating the warden so he just kept me over there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay as a favor.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Just because it would be easier than coming over there?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It kept me as close to my family as possible. It's good.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Absolutely and then you made the move to hunt for classification and then here so how old were you when you finally ended up here at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: 25, tell me about that. What was that transition like for you?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well once I get here, I hadn't really accepted this as my home, once I got here because the when I got on this charge the guy that with me he tried things on me so it was like I'm done.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you knew this was a life means life.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you probably heard stories about Angola and how violent this place could be and so forth were any of those stories true.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah and it was still violent when I came but not bad but it was regular.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Every day you had to getting jugged hit in the head.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right did you find yourself getting into fights here when you first got here?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I had a few.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Cell blocks time in the cell blocks or.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: No in population.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Population, so tell me something when you look back on the 25 year old Elliot can you describe him?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Didn't care. He was all by his self didn't care about nobody if you hurt somebody it didn't matter didn't care about myself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah and how are you different now.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well I got God in my life for one and that's someone that anybody could tell you even George I know he heard me say many time I never go to church I die here and all that has changed now I'm a believer and I think if god in your life anybody can change.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure and how have you changed?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I go to church now for one and that's something I never done in years I mean they too so many people that begged me to go to church and I can stand now and talk to anybody about god that's something I couldn't do.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When did that happen when did that change happen for you.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: 2016 actually when I had met this lady at the rodeo and she had asked me her if I go to church and I told her no. so she like you mean to tell me you don't go to church I said no so she said baby she said you need god in your life she said you done gave up and I'm laughing but I'm like how she now this here cause I been saying for years twenty thirty years I'm going to die here.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: So she said you need god in your life so she said I'll be here next week I said I'll be right here too so next week she came she said you remember what I told you I said what I thought about that all week I said after the rodeo I said we'll go to church and she said ok I got your work I said yeah and from that day on first I told her about my incident I got electrocuted.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh yeah why don't you tell me about that?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I was at work one morning and they had a raccoon on the building.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was your job?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Mechanic.So I went over there to get the raccoon and when I hit the raccoon I hit the telephone line and I got electrocuted 3 times before I got knocked off the building.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Whew so you ended up and I can see some scars on your arms. You end up in the hospital.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I stayed in the hospital a month in the street and a month up here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: My God.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Got my arm my back all my stomach most of the side of my stomach burnt up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you still have any do you still feel the repercussions of it or are you completely back to normal?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It still itches.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: It still do a lot of itching.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Form the burn.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: So I got to take a medication for the itching.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright but otherwise you're doing. So when did this happen.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: August 14th 2015.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's right earlier you had said it's almost the three year anniversary.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Three years yesterday.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yesterday, so you're talking to this lady from the rodeo and tells you to go to church and so this is this is like yesterday in the grand scheme of things.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right yeah from and we went through wound up dating and we been together ever since. And she always tells me that stay focused because she knows god and told her about how I stayed in trouble and how she can change me and all that So she always keeps on my mind stay focused stay focused cause things gone work out and she been with me every step of the way since.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah that's interesting how does that work how do you manage to find a way to make a relationship work while you're in prison.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well like she said you got to be strong because just like your family come to see you it's hard for me to watch her leave and that's why my brother he don't like coming up here cause he don't want to see me in here but he demand to exit here but he tell me he said I can't come and I understand that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah so really Elliott when I think about it you've for the most of your so most of your life in prison has been kind of behind a feeling of hopelessness

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And thinking just convince yourself you're going to die here and this is it and whatever not caring about anybody else or yourself from what you're your own words. And all of this changes just in 2016.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Actually when I got electrocuted I was laying the hospital. I started going to church in 2016 but when I got electrocuted in 2015 I was laying in the hospital and a little voice told me it said you're not going to die here. Said because if you was today was your day and from that day on I have never told nobody anymore that I'm gone die here I got hope now and went to the pardon board got a recommendation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right so tell me about the pardon board

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Classification came to see me in 2003 to go on the pardon board and I ran away from myself cause I told them I said I ain't never going home I'm going to die here and the man looked at them and said "Man you serious he said you crazy." He said, "You the first person I ever heard said you don't want to go home." I said, "I ain't going home" I said, "Ain't nobody getting out here man people going to die here." And he walked with me from my cell but after I met this lady all of that change I got on the pardon board got a recommendation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So in January your life sentence was commuted to.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Commuted to 99 years 45 years parole eligibility.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Which will be 15 years from now unless something changes.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Unless something changes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Hopefully and so that's changed your life so what other ways does that change the way your daily life here you go from years of hopelessness.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well I hang everybody I hang around now is positive people. I don't fool with people that stays in trouble everybody I mentioned is positive the hobby shop or probably talking about going home stuff like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's interesting to me is that alcohol and drugs and whatever that was medicating was so clearly part of what got you into this position and yet from the day you were incarcerated you stopped using drugs and alcohol completely?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah because in our parish you can't get drugs like talk about it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok great did you go through the 12 step programs here for drug and alcohol abuse?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I went through a little program called safe care it was like 12 step program for alcohol and drugs in our parish jail and the girl that I went to school with she had the program and I went through that with her.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about some other organizations or some of the other programs you've taken advantage of at Angola I'm sure you had to list some of these things when you went before the pardon board.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah I done went through anger management went through 100 hours and AA I went through up here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What did you learn in anger management?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well I can control my anger now because a lot of times I'd go off with I got to have the last say but now I learn just walk away. It don't matter what they say just walk away

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right yeah. So tell me about what's your routine now you're still working as a mechanic

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I still work over there but I'm a tool merchant now a stock clerk I check tools out every day check them back in at the end of the day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And how many hours a day do you do that?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: 8 hours.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: 40 hours a week.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What do you do when you've got some down time?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Like on the weekends or after 3 o'clock when we're done work hobby shop. And I go to school at night for my GED.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright and all of this has started since 2016.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Very interesting so let me ask you a little a couple of difficult things so it's been 30 years when you look back on what happened to get you here even though as you said earlier in some strange way it saved your life what are your feelings about it when you think back on the victim and the impact of what you did had on the victim's family after 30 years I don't know what I mean I don't know what I would be feeling.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Remorse. I could feel they pain what they're going through and what I bring my family through.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok do you think that watching your own family struggle with seeing you come to prison helped you understand how it might be for the victims' family?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Yeah especially the little boy he grew up without a dad he was like 3 years old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about, tell me about the impact of your being incarcerated on your own family, how did it affect them.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well I I've seen all my nieces and nephews grow up here and they love me like we grew up out there together I mean even though I still don't know them but seeing them here still don't make me know them and that's a lot just to see know that they love me that much to come see me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure who do you think it's been hardest on in your family to have you come here?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My mom, and my sister older sister and my dad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you notice like how did it impact them?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Because majority of the time and my nieces too they cry a lot when it's time for them to go but my dad he when it's time for him to go he really don't want to look at me he just walks on off.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: It's too painful how does your mom cope.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: She sometimes she cries and I had to. She moved to Denver. She stayed at Denver 15 years, because when I first got arrested the guy I was on the charge with, he threatened them. Threatened the family which is, he's my cousin. He threatened them that if I'd say something that he would kill them. So my mom they got scared, they moved to Denver. To my little sister.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow does your cousin, is he also incarcerated serving a life sentence.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: No he done 5 years for accessory.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok so he pulled out and testified against you.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me something you've been here if you've been incarcerated for 30 years you've seen just about everything you can see in this experience what's been the worst part of it for you what's been worst about this experience.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I would say my worst it's just what you got to go through every day I mean.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah for people who haven't been to prison explain that.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I mean you got 5,000 different attitudes personalities you don't know who it is you sleeping by today or tonight so a lot of times you can't sleep. You might have your bed partner this morning he got a lot on his mind but you can tell something wrong with him he don't want to talk so you're like what's wrong so now you got to watch him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You mean today you got to worry about things like that.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right he might go off on you never know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I mean just the stress of being in this place is that what you mean.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So what are you proudest of?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Getting back to school for one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Because that's something I said I would never do talking about I don't need a GED to die in prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I mean I felt that was ridiculous. And for me to get back in school that meant a lot to me and I'm going to strive all I could to get my GED.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you're already doing that how much more time do you think it'll take you to finish.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Hopefully not long hopefully by the end of the year.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right, so when you get released from here, I hope it's before the 45 years. What are you, how do you envision your life, what's your plan?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Work. I mean I love working it's not like I was to fail if you ain't got your own you don't have nothing so everything I've ever dreamed of I know I can't have but I can get some of it and that a racecar that's what I was doing when I first got locked up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You had a race car?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Well the guy I was working for we built a racecar.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow what kind of car.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Quarter mile 70 Cheval.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well you're a mechanic, so you can save some money there.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you're going to build a racecar when you get out.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: My brother he already got him one. And he told me, you're going to build a bike or a car because he know I like to ride the bikes too, the motorcycles.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah me too.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: And I told him I said well I'll probably get me a bike but I'd rather get me a car too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right, so what kind of car are you thinking about?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: A little Opal GT.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ok yeah sure so that's part of it work get a car what else

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Raise a family.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh really.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: I plan on getting married.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you plan on getting married to the woman that you are with now?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And where does she live.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Zachary.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So would that be the place where you would move to?

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did she come to your pardon hearing? Was she here or in Baton Rouge.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: She was here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright, well I've enjoyed learning about you I'm sorry to learn about the electrocution but I appreciate you sitting with us and talking is there something else I should have asked you about that you think is important for me to learn about you that we didn't get a chance to talk about.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Not really.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right well I appreciate it and I wish you all the best.

transcript.speaker: Elliott
transcript.content: Okay.
